image.altText: A graphic image of a woman whose brain is visible, split in glitching pieces

items.synopsis: The next frontier of Australia's concussion crisis isn't on the football field, but in homes across the country, where victims of domestic violence are sustaining brain injuries at staggering rates.

title.children: Another concussion crisis is erupting — out of sight, undiagnosed and ignored

image.altText: Indigenous dancers perform during a bunggul.

items.synopsis: Bungguls are the main attraction at Garma Festival, in north-east Arnhem Land. But this year is the first festival without Gumatj trailblazer Yunupiŋu.

title.children: Bungguls are one of Australia's oldest ceremonies. So, what does it involve?

image.altText: A close up shot of some lottery balls.

items.synopsis: You might have heard stories about lottery winners in the US losing a big chunk of their money to taxes. But what are the rules in Australia?

title.children: How much tax do you have to pay for lottery winnings? It depends on what you do with it

image.altText: Latisha Butt Bonny Photography

items.synopsis: While social media has long been called out for presenting narrow ideas of body image, Tamika McCall says her boudoir photography sessions are more fun and empowering, than sexy.

title.children: Former weight-loss 'yoyo-er' learning self-acceptance through boudoir photography

image.altText: A young Indian woman with dark hair looks at the camera. She's wearing a dark red jumper and wears a cross necklace.

items.synopsis: Juliet hopes to study medicine and become a doctor to help address the dire shortage of health professionals in Australia's regions. But her family has been waiting for eight years to gain permanent residency.

title.children: Juliet's dream is to be a doctor, but she can't afford it. She's one of Australia's thousands of 'permanently temporary' migrants

image.altText: A man in a shirt and jacket sits at a wooden table and smiles for the camera.

items.synopsis: A Victorian government MP has been forced to quit the parliamentary Labor Party over an alleged assault, Premier Daniel Andrews says.

title.children: Victorian Labor MP quits parliamentary party over assault allegations, Premier Daniel Andrews says

image.altText: A white haired dog with patches of brown nuzzles his nose into a bag filled with ice on a footpath.

items.synopsis: The United States' brutal heatwaves are particularly punishing in Arizona, where cacti are suddenly collapsing under extreme temperatures. But one city has found some creative ways to combat the heat.

title.children: Mobile cooling stations and freezing IV: The struggle for survival in America’s hottest city

image.altText: a queenslander, mid-rise and high-rise in a graphic

items.synopsis: You have to build up to stop building out. But can higher housing density bring about affordability?

title.children: It's one of Australia's fastest growing regions, but can we get past our 'fear of density' to house everyone?

image.altText: Donald Trump, holding an umbrella in the rain, speaks to reporters at an airport.

items.synopsis: US prosecutors flagged a threatening social media post from Donald Trump in a late-night court filing, arguing that it suggests he might intimidate witnesses by improperly disclosing confidential evidence received from the government.

title.children: 'IF YOU GO AFTER ME, I'M COMING AFTER YOU!': Trump's social media post flagged by US prosecutors to judge

image.altText: A polce car with its red and blue lights on in a dark street.

items.synopsis: Police say they were confronted by a 29-year-old man who was known to officers, and that no-one else was injured in the incident.

title.children: Queensland police shoot man dead while executing search warrant north of Brisbane

image.altText: Young Chinese boys play games on their phones.

items.synopsis: The Chinese government is considering making so-called "minor modes" mandatory on all mobile devices to limit the amount of time they can be used by young people. But some parents, children and experts think the restrictions don't address the real issues.

title.children: We asked Chinese parents and children what they thought of Beijing's plan to limit kids access to mobile devices

image.altText: A Kokatha woman with black hair pulled back wears a black shirt that reads 'Always' in gold and stands against wooden wall

items.synopsis: The first work by artistic director Frances Rings is a cautionary tale inspired by a precious, ancient water source hidden under the desert, which was drained dry and is now 'resting'.

title.children: Cautionary tale about ancient water source hidden beneath desert the subject of major new work

image.altText: A young football fan holding an Australia scarf

items.synopsis: Can Australia's soccer industry use the World Cup momentum to grow the game domestically?

title.children: The FIFA Women's World Cup, as seen through the eyes of its youngest fans

image.altText: Aerial view of eight netball courts surrounded by trees and a car park on left

items.synopsis: Why this competition-grade netball facility opened a year ago still hasn't hosted a game

title.children: Why these brand new inner Melbourne netball courts are sitting empty

image.altText: An Australian Diamonds goal keeper catches the ball while off the ground, as a Jamaican goal shooter looks dejected behind her.

items.synopsis: For the first time in 28 years, the Netball World Cup won't be decided by a trans-Tasman battle in the final, as England break a 48-year drought to reach the top two.

title.children: Diamonds beat Jamaica to reach Netball World Cup final

image.altText: A Golden Bandicoot being held in a pair of open hands

items.synopsis: Species which once roamed freely now thrive in a fenced-in safe haven created in Sturt National Park, part of one of the world's biggest mammal reintroduction projects.

title.children: Scientists successfully reintroduce locally extinct mammals to safe fenced-in zones

image.altText: Di Harcourt with her dog Sammy, in front of a black and white photo portrait of herself.

items.synopsis: When Di got the call that there was community housing with her name on it, it changed her life. A new portrait installation is helping to tell her story — and tackle stereotypes.

title.children: 'I knew in my heart this was it': Community housing offered Di stability after years of moving around

image.altText: Anthony Albanese walking on a red dirt road surrounded by people in body paint carrying red flags

items.synopsis: The prime minister has made clear that fear of the Voice referendum failing will not stop him from keeping his word to the late Yolngu leader and land rights legend Yunupiŋu, writes Patricia Karvelas.

title.children: Anthony Albanese stares down calls for rethink on timing of the Voice referendum

image.altText: Pakistan's former prime minister Imran Khan sits on a couch pointing in the air

items.synopsis: Legal experts say the conviction could end Khan's chances of participating in national elections that have to be held before early November.

title.children: Former Pakistan prime minister Imran Khan sentenced to three years in prison

image.altText: A woman, man, and two young girls, all dressed in green football jerseys smile at the camera.

items.synopsis: As the Matildas are celebrated for their success at the FIFA Women's World Cup, we turn the spotlight on the grassroots heroes — the beating heartbeat of the game.

title.children: Meet the local heroes championing women's football around Australia

image.altText: Woman drinking wine from a glass, in profile

items.synopsis: Even drinking in moderation — one or two drinks each day over the week — is risky. Here are some tips for incorporating alcohol-free days into your routine.

title.children: A glass of wine each night or many over a big weekend — is one healthier than the other?

image.altText: Players competing for the ball

items.synopsis: Japan and Spain both put their hands up as World Cup contenders with impressive wins in their round of 16 clashes.

title.children: Japan and Spain impress in progressing to World Cup quarter-finals, Kerr says she'll play

image.altText: An oil tanker is moored.

items.synopsis: A Russian tanker is damaged in a Ukrainian drone attack in the Kerch Strait, briefly halting traffic on the strategic bridge linking Crimea to Russia, Russian maritime officials say.

title.children: Russia says tanker hit by sea drone in Ukrainian attack near Crimea bridge

image.altText: A man in a grey jumper sits on a bed in a room with a tv, and paintings on the wall.

items.synopsis: There's a common cycle for many children in this town: Crime, watch house, detention. Background Briefing investigates why.

title.children: Marty woke to find three intruders in his bedroom. His story is one of hundreds from his hometown

image.altText: aerial view of dead mangroves

items.synopsis: Environmental advocates have developed a detailed strategy to restore a polluted mangrove forest in Adelaide's north, and prevent future damage.

title.children: Strategic plan paves pathway to recovery for threatened St Kilda mangroves

image.altText: A young woman smiles in front of a pop-up gazebo tent

items.synopsis: It's a busy Saturday night and a group has set up a pop-up gazebo tent, chairs and a first aid kit. Their mission is to help people enjoying a night out get home safely.

title.children: When Kristen turned 18, she could have hit Sydney's nightlife. But she's decided to keep others safe

image.altText: People causing damage to car

items.synopsis: Thousands scrambled to catch a glimpse of 2022's "Streamer of the Year" Kai Cenat and the chance to get free gaming products at his giveaway event in New York City.

title.children: Scenes of chaos at live streamer's New York giveaway event, as arrests and injuries ensue

image.altText: A Wallabies player reacts after the loss to the All Blacks in the Bledisloe Cup.

items.synopsis: While their fans may be encouraged by the performance against the All Blacks, the Wallabies are left to rue a missed opportunity after blowing a sizeable lead in the second Bledisloe Cup Test in Dunedin.

title.children: Five quick hits – Wallabies reminded Test rugby is an 80-minute game as All Blacks reign supreme

image.altText: Aerial photo shows rescue workers deploy life rafts for evacuating residents during floods.

items.synopsis: Struggling with the city's heaviest rainfall in at least 140 years, Beijing officials make the decision to divert floodwaters elsewhere, causing devastation in cities like Zhuozhou, which one official described as "a moat for the capital".

title.children: Beijing floodwaters diverted as anger sparked over plans to use outer cities as 'moat for the capital'

image.altText: A crab with its pincers out and a man and woman

items.synopsis: A crab-tying champion and a couple on their perpetual honeymoon try to explain why this out-of-the-way Queensland hamlet is paradise.

title.children: Meet Jason, the 'pirate' of Stanage Bay, a fishing town so idyllic some visitors never leave
